Award.AwardTitle: The Interplay Between Grain Size and Austenite Stability on Constitutive Deformation Behavior of High Strength-High Ductility Combination Nanostructured Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
The objective of this research project is to determine the fundamental criteria for obtaining a combination of high strength and high ductility in metals with grain sizes in the nanometer range. These criteria will be elucidated by conducting controlled mechanical deformation experiments at different rates using a nanoindenter. Subsequently, the indented region will be examined via microscopy tools. Experiments utilize the increasing the stability of the principal constituent phase with decreasing in grain size. The criteria investigated define if the stability of the principal constituent phase of the metallic material is responsible for governing the ductility of high-strength metallic materials. Changes in deformation behavior will be studied as a function of grain size from the nanograin regime through the conventional micrometer regime. Physical models with predictive capabilities for a wide range of material systems based on the relationship between grain size and stability of the principal constituent phase will be developed.


NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
The results of this research will extend the state-of-art for processing of high-strength, high-ductility alloys with superior formabilities. The understanding of deformation mechanisms underlying combined high strength and high ductility is expected to be important in guiding the development of future strong and ductile metallic materials. The ultimate objective is to determine guidelines to pioneer a new frontier of materials for light and efficient solutions involving energy absorption and formability. Furthermore, new techniques will be developed to understand material behavior that will be applicable to other metallic systems. Both graduate and undergraduate students will be trained in metals research under this program. High-school students will be engaged in science and technology through summer programs.

Institution.Name: University of Texas at El Paso
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS AT EL PASO

Performance_Institution.Name: University of Texas at El Paso

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nanostructured metals an alloys characterized by high strength-high ductility combination are excellent vehicles to obtain an unambiguous understanding of deformation mechanisms vis-à-vis their conventional coarse-grained counterpart. In this context, the innovative concept of phase reversion-induced nanograined structure enabled achieving high strength without compromising ductility, for instance, in metastable austenitic stainless steels. In the phase reversion process, severe deformation of austenite at room temperature (typically 60-80%) transformed face-centered cubic austenite to body centered cubic martensite. Upon annealing, martensite reverted to austenite leading to extensive grain refinement. The objective of the project was to fundamentally understand the deformation mechanisms in nanograined structure in relation to the coarse-grained structure. This was accomplished by combining depth-sensing nanoscale experiments in austenitic stainless steels conducted at different strain rates, followed by the study of structural evolution in the deformed zone using transmission electron microscopy. In the high strength nanograined austenitic stainless steel (yield strength - 585 MPa), stacking faults and nanotwins contributed to the enhanced ductility (elongation - 35%), while in the case of low strength (yield strength - 260 MPa) coarse-grained counterpart, ductility was also high (elongation - 40%), but because of strain-induced martensite. This pointed to the clear case of grain size effect (and the corresponding level of strength). The distinct change in the deformation mechanism from stacking faults and twinning-induced plasticity (TWIP) in the nanograined structure to transformation-induced plasticity (TRIP) in the coarse-grained structure was elucidated in terms of austenite stability-strain energy relationship. The insights on the relationship between grain structure (and strength) and deformation mechanisms are envisaged to be important in providing a new direction for the futuristic design of high strength-high ductility nanograined materials such as austenitic stainless steels and twinning induced plasticity steels. 

The students working on the project acquired training in the processing of nanostructured metallic alloys and in the use of advanced materials characterization techniques.


Last Modified: 03/04/2017
Modified by: Devesh Misra

In this context, the innovative concept of phase reversion-induced nanograined structure enabled achieving high strength without compromising ductility, for instance, in metastable austenitic stainless steels. The students working on the project acquired training in the processing of nanostructured metallic alloys and in the use of advanced materials characterization techniques.
